editionStmt.funder: Conversion of the printed catalogue to TEI funded by the Warden and Fellows of Merton College .

msItem.note: For endleaves see below. Fol. 1 blank.

msItem.author: RAMON LULL
msItem.title: Disputatio Heremitae et Raymundi
msItem.rubric: Deus qui es summus in omnibus bonis ad tuam laudem et honorem. Incipit disputacio heremite et Raymundi super aliquibus dubiis questionibus sentenciarum Magistri Petri Lombardi.
msItem.incipit: Raymundus Parisius studens statumque mundi huius peruersum considerans
msItem.finalRubric: De fine huius libri. Finiuit Raymundus uerba sua laudando et benedicendo Deum ... in quorum custodia Raymundus hunc librum commendauit. Iste liber finitus est in ciuitate Parisiensi anno incarnacionis Domini nostri M. CC. XXVIII in octabis assumpcionis domine nostre beate Marie
msItem.note: ed. I. Salzinger, Beati Raymundi Lulli ... Opera (Mainz, 1721–9), IV, pp. 1–119; Glorieux, Théol. 335bv; Stegmüller, Sent. 711, 1; Diaz 1791. Followed on fol. 109–11 by a table of the quaestiones. fol. 111v blank.

msItem.author: RAMON LULL
msItem.title: Declaratio Raimundi
msItem.rubric: Deus ad tuam honorem incipit declaracio Raymundi per modum dyalogi edita contra aliquorum philosophorum et eorum sequacium oppositiones erroneas dampnatas a uenerabili patre episcopo Parisiensi.
msItem.incipit: In quadam silua iuxta Parisius stabat Raymundus tristis et desolatus
msItem.note: Ed. P. O. Keicher, BGPTM 7 (1909), pp. 95–221; Glorieux, Théol. 335bu; Diaz 1790.

msItem.author: RAMON LULL
msItem.title: De Lumine
msItem.incipit: Quoniam intellectus multiplicat species attrahendo similitudines
msItem.finalRubric: Ad honorem Dei finiuit Raymundus librum de lumine in Monte Pessulano mensis Nouembris M. CCC. III incarnacionis Domini nostri Iesu Christi amen. LAUS DEO

msItem.author: RAMON LULL
msItem.title: De Anima Rationali
msItem.incipit: Quoniam anima racionalis est substancia inuisibilis
msItem.finalRubric: Finitus fuit iste liber Rome in ciuitate per magistrum Raymundum anno incarnationis D. n. I. C. millesimo ducentesimo nonagesimo tercio ... LAUS DEO PATRI FILIO SANCTO SPIRITUI INDIVIDUE TRINITATI AMEN
msItem.note: ed. Salzinger, VI, pp. 1–60; Glorieux, Théol. 335bn; Diaz 1782.

msItem.author: RAMON LULL
msItem.title: Disputatio Fidei et Intellectus
msItem.incipit: Theologorum studia ianuam sciencie sibi cupientium aperiri debent meditacione
msItem.note: ed. Salzinger, IV, pp. 1–26; Glorieux, Théol. 335cx; Diaz 1813.

msItem.author: RAMON LULL
msItem.title: De Ascensu et Descensu Intellectus
msItem.incipit: intelligendo alioquin uoluntas scientiam generaret sine intellectu
msItem.explicit: et uniunt aliam personam per amorem
msItem.note: CCSL cont. med. 35 (1981), pp. 58 line 490–151 line 467; Glorieux, Théol. 335dk; Diaz 1827, not this copy.

The table of contents notes of this art. ‘Item in fine continentur sex quaterni de quodam tractatu eiusdem de naturis rerum. Sed desunt illic multi quaterni a principio eiusdem operis quod nusquam potuimus reperire.’ There are only five quires now.

supportDesc.collation: two singletons at each end, 1–228, 236, 24–98, 30–16, 32–88, 386, 3910(lacks 3–9; 10 mutil.); catchwords; quire-signatures of the usual late medieval form. At the foot of fol. 268 (beginning of quire 35) the hand of the quire-signatures (which is perhaps that of the table of contents) has written ‘Hic desunt multi quaterni’.

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled with fine pencil in 2 cols of 33 lines.

handDesc.handNote: The humanistic bookhand of John Pacy, who also wrote CCCC 158, and wrote and signed Cambridge, Pembroke Coll. MS 235 in 1464.

decoDesc.decoNote: Initials in colours and gold: on fol. 2 initial and 3-sided border; on fols. 112, 162, 184, 244, initial and 2-sided border; on fols. 34, 75, 95, 108, 113 (2), 114rv coloured initials and sprays. Otherwise blue initials flourished in red.

binding.p: Contemporary; thin, slightly chamfered oak boards with slightly projecting squares, bared and rebacked with modern vellum, sewn on five bands; on the rear board is nailed the usual label under horn with Fitzjames’ arms and ex dono. At one stage a much larger one appears to have been nailed to the front board, extending over the spine covering.

history.provenance: On fol. 1v, in the usual untidy secretary hand, a long table of contents followed by ‘Ex dono domini Ricardi Fitz James nuper Cicestrensis episcopi et custodis istius collegii’. For Fitzjames, see MS 9; the dolphin from his arms is in the opening initial on fol. 2. ‘9’ (altered from ?’16’) is inked on the foredge.
On fol. 1v is ‘N. 7. 9. Art:’, s. xvii, and the College bookplate, together with ‘LXXXIX’.

source.bibl: R. M. Thomson, A descriptive catalogue of the medieval manuscripts of Merton College, Oxford (Cambridge: D. S. Brewer), 2009.

availability.p: For enquiries relating to this manuscript please contact Merton College Library.

listBibl.bibl: Coxe, pp. 47–8; Powicke, no. 1187; Duke Humfrey and English Humanism in the Fifteenth Century (Oxford, The Bodleian Library, 1970), no. 89; Alexander & Temple, no. 588.

decoDesc.decoNote: Unfilled spaces for coloured initials and rubrics.

layoutDesc.layout: Two flattened bifolia, bound in sideways. Written in 2 cols of more than 56 lines.
